{{DISPLAYTITLE:iCivics}} '''iCivics, inc.''' (formerly Our Courts) is a [[501(c)(3)]] [[non-profit organization]] in the United States that provides [[Educational game|educational online games]] and lesson plans to promote [[civics]] education and encourage students to become active citizens.<ref name=":0" /> iCivics was founded in 2008 by retired [[Supreme Court of the United States]] Justice [[Sandra Day O'Connor]]. iCivics’s stated mission is to “ensure every student receives a high-quality civic education, and becomes engaged in – and beyond – the classroom.”<ref name=":1" />
iCivics, inc. is supported by private donations and grants and had annual expenses of $2.2 million in 2015.<ref name=":0" /> Among the top contributors were the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation|Gates Foundation]] and the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation|MacArthur Foundation]].<ref name=":0">iCivics, Inc. (2016). ''iCivics Annual Report 2015''. Retrieved from https://www.icivics.org/sites/default/files/annual_report_2015.pdf</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.macfound.org/grantees/392/|title=iCivics — MacArthur Foundation|website=www.macfound.org|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref> In the same year, iCivics served more than 85,000 educators and 3 million students, including half of all middle school [[social studies]] classrooms in America.<ref name=":0" />
==History== Justice O’Connor developed the Our Courts project in partnership with [[Georgetown University Law School]] and [[Arizona State University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icivics.org/news/icivics-celebrates-gaming-milestone|title=iCivics Celebrates Gaming Milestone|last=Curley|first=Jeffrey|publisher=iCivics|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://cabengo.com/projects/our-courts/|title=Cabengo » Our Courts|website=cabengo.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> In March 2009, Justice O'Connor went on [[The Daily Show]] with [[Jon Stewart]] to promote Our Courts and civics education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/videos/index.jhtml?videoId=220242&title=sandra-day-o-connor-pt--1|title=Justice O'Connor Interview|last=The Daily Show|publisher=The Daily Show|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2009/03/04/justice-oconnor-not-only-smart-and-moderate-but-funny/|title=Justice O'Connor: Not Only Smart and Moderate...But Funny!|last=Jones|first=Ashby|date=4 March 2009|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref> Our Courts added ''Supreme Decision'' and ''Do I Have A Right?'' to the website in August 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.edweek.org/login.html?source=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2009/08/20/01civics.h29.html&destination=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2009/08/20/01civics.h29.html&levelId=2100|title=Celebrities Lend Weight to Promote Civics Education|date=August 20, 2009 (updated August 25, 2009)|work=[[Education Week]]|publisher=Education Week|author=Zehr, Mary Ann|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref> It was incorporated as iCivics, inc. in May 2010 as the variety of content and users began to expand more rapidly.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.icivics.org/news/introducing-our-new-site|title=Introducing our new site {{!}} iCivics|website=www.icivics.org|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> A more comprehensive website was launched, supplementing the gaming modules with classroom lessons on the branches of government.
[[Above the Law (blog)|Above The Law]] sponsored a ''Do I Have A Right?'' challenge in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abovethelaw.com/2010/01/the-atl-do-i-have-a-right-challengecongratulations-from-justice-oconnor/|title=The ATL ‘Do I Have A Right?’ Challenge: Congratulations from Justice O’Connor|last=Lat|first=David|publisher=Above The Law|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref> Justice O'Connor was the keynote speaker at [[Games for Change]] in 2010, and iCivics was featured at the Games for Change conference in New York in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/charles-tsai/al-gore-games-social-good_b_881017.html|title=Al Gore: 'Games Are the New Normal'|last=Tsai|first=Charles|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref> The [[Washington Post]] Editorial Board highlighted the shortcomings of traditional civics education, and the efforts of iCivics.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/making-history-and-civics-a-priority/2011/06/17/AGb1tYZH_story.html|title=Making History and Civics a Priority|last=Editorial Board|date=17 June 2011|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref>
In 2011 the website added seven games and 16 lesson plans, and had over 700,000 unique visitors.<ref>iCivics, Inc. (2012). ''Annual Report 2011''. Retrieved from www.guidestar.org/ViewEdoc.aspx?eDocId=2772999&approved=True</ref> By 2013 it was the most widely adopted civics curriculum in America.<ref name=":3" />
Currently, the governing board of iCivics includes O’Connor as well as current Justice Sonia Sotomayor and the Honorable Robert Henry, president of Oklahoma City University. The executive director of iCivics is Louise Dubé, previously Managing Director of Digital Learning at [[WGBH-TV|WGBH]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icivics.org/our-team|title=Our Team {{!}} iCivics|website=www.icivics.org|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref>
==Mission== Justice O’Connor initially envisioned Our Courts as a response to a perceived misunderstanding of the justice system in America.<ref name=":2" /> As keynote speaker at the [[National Council for the Social Studies|NCSS]] annual conference in 2007, she noted “that while two-thirds of Americans know at least two judges on FOX Television’s ‘American Idol’ reality program, less than one in 10 can name the Chief Justice of the United States.” <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.americanbar.org/newsletter/publications/law_matters_home/oconnor.html|title=Law Matters Winter 2008 {{!}} Justice O'Connor Addresses NCSS Conference|website=www.americanbar.org|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> At present, ourcourts.org maintains this mission,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ourcourts.org/our-approach/|title=Our Approach - Our Courts America|website=ourcourts.org|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> but iCivics has a broader mission incorporating education on the legislative and executive branches of government as well as civics at a local level.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.guidestar.org/profile/38-3796793|title=iCivics - GuideStar Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=www.guidestar.org|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-25|quote=Self-reported}}</ref>
The organization focuses on broadly improving civics education but also on closing the civics [[Achievement gap in the United States|education gap]].<ref name=":0" /> O'Connor saw the state of civics education as a result of the failure of traditional education methods, as well as funding cuts and lower graduation requirements imposed by the [[No Child Left Behind Act]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nea.org/home/38146.htm|title=Courting Kids|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> Our Courts collaborator [[James Paul Gee|James Gee]], a professor of literacy at Arizona State University, convinced her that educational games were the key to civics education, due to their capacity to teach problem solving.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/28/technology/sandra-day-oconnor-supreme-court-video-games.html|title=A Supreme Court Pioneer, Now Making Her Mark on Video Games|last=Singer|first=Natasha|date=2016-03-27|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref>
iCivics games have been evaluated for their educational effectiveness in a handful of research studies. ''Branches of Power'' was shown to be both engaging and educational for a majority of students in a test group.<ref>Lewis, Carrie, Jason Lancaster, Wilhelmina Savenye, and Nancy Haas. "A Formative Evaluation of the Balance of Power Game and Curriculum." ''The Journal of Applied Instructional Design'' 3, no. 3 (December 2013): 5-16.</ref> A significant number of students also play the games again at home, greatly increasing absorption of concepts and improving test scores.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://trevorowens.org/portfolio/owens_Effects%20of%20learning%20from%20a%20civics%20video%20game.doc|title=Effects of learning from a civics video game|last=Owens|first=Trevor|date=December 2010|website=Trevor Owens|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> The general iCivics curriculum has been shown to be an effective mechanism for education on civics topics as measured by scores on the US citizenship test. It was particularly effective among younger students in grades 4-6 and less effective among high school seniors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=LeCompte|first=Karen|last2=Moore|first2=Brandon|last3=Blevins|first3=Brooke|date=Fall 2011|title=The Impact of iCivics on Students’ Core Civic Knowledge|url=|journal=Research in the Schools|volume=18|issue=2|doi=|pmid=|via=}}</ref> The interactive writing exercise Drafting Board also improved [[persuasive writing]] skills among 8th graders.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://civicyouth.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/WP_76_KawashimaGinsberg.pdf|title=Summary of Findings from the Evaluation of iCivics’ Drafting Board Intervention|last=Kawashima-Ginsberg|first=Kei|date=December 2012|website=CIRCLE|publisher=THE CENTER FOR INFORMATION & RESEARCH ON CIVIC LEARNING & ENGAGEMENT|access-date=}}</ref>
The organization is currently working on extending its curriculum to high school and reaching more high school educators. It currently serves one in four high school government and history teachers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.guidestar.org/profile/38-3796793|title=iCivics - GuideStar Profile|website=www.guidestar.org|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref>
==Content== iCivics hosts lesson plans, games, online workshops and other materials for teachers and students of American civics. All online materials are free to registered users.
=== Games === iCivics currently hosts nineteen different educational games, developed in partnership with [[Filament Games]] (with the exception of Supreme Decision, produced with Studio Mobile, Cabengo and the Center for Children & Technology).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icivics.org/credits|title=Credits {{!}} iCivics|website=www.icivics.org|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref> Curriculum and design of each game is provided by employees of iCivics, and dart, programming, and sound design is provided by Filament. * Activate - Build an advocacy campaign from the local to the national level. * Argument Wars - Argue one of several landmark Supreme Court cases. * Branches of Power - Control the three different branches of federal government. * Cast Your Vote - Interview candidates for office in a debate setting and try to vote for the one you most agree with. * Counties Work - Control a municipal government, balancing taxes with public services and helping the community grow. * Court Quest - help citizens resolve cases by guiding them through the different parts of the court system. * Crisis of Nations - As Commander-in-Chief, take military and diplomatic action to promote the national interest. * Do I Have A Right? - field a team of specialist lawyers in Constitutional litigation cases. * Do I Have A Right?: Bill of Rights Edition - field a team of lawyers with specialties in each of the [[United States Bill of Rights|first ten amendments.]] * Executive Command - As President of the United States, take responsibility for giving the [[State of the Union]] speech, signing legislation, running the departments of the executive branch, negotiating with other branches of government and other nations, and deciding on military aid, war and diplomacy efforts. * Immigration Nation - decide who is allowed to immigrate to the US by determining their citizenship, work visa or refugee status. * Lawcraft - Bring a bill through Congress, compromising with other legislators and adding amendments until it passes and becomes law. * People's Pie - Control the budget for the federal government by selecting tax revenue, borrowing level, and spending programs which the public will approve. * Power Play - Argue the respective advantages of state power and federal power. * Represent Me! - As a legislator, strategically support bills which will help your constituents most. * Responsibility Launcher - remind people of their civic duties and privileges as citizens of the United States. * Supreme Decision - help decide a court case on student dress policy, similar to [[Tinker v. Des Moines Independent Community School District|Tinker v. Des Moines]]. * We The Jury - as a jurist, hear a case, weigh the arguments and evidence, and persuade fellow jurists to come to a specific conclusion on the case. * Win the White House - manage a presidential campaign by strategically raising funds, polling voters, launching media campaigns, and making personal appearances. Attempt to win the majority of electoral votes.
=== Lesson plans === Lesson plans on iCivics are also provided for free, with content and curriculum guidance provided by iCivics staff. These plans emphasize student engagement by including activities such as crosswords and short quizzes as well as reference to their online games. Units of study include the history and development of the Constitution, the branches and levels of government, the rights and duties of citizens, politics and policy, and international affairs. Beyond education on government, there is also a unit on persuasive writing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icivics.org/products/lesson-plans|title=Lesson Plans {{!}} iCivics|website=www.icivics.org|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref> A set of lessons developed with the [[Boys & Girls Clubs of America]] was designed to be used during their meetings instead of a traditional school period.<ref>Boys and Girls Clubs of America. (2013). ''2012 annual report.'' Retrieved from<nowiki/>http://www.bgca.org/whoweare/Documents/2012_Annual_ReportLOW.pdf</ref>
==References== <references/>

{{Infobox book | name = Lazzat Un Nisa
{{lang|ar|لذّتُ النّسا}} | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | author = Mohammed Abdul Latif Muzdar Mehdune | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[India]] | language = [[Urdu]], [[Persian language|Persian]] | series = | subject = [[Eroticism]] | genre = [[Erotica]] | publisher = | publisher2 = | pub_date = 1850 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | awards = | isbn = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | wikisource = }} '''''Lazzat Un Nisa''''' (from {{lang-ar|'''لذّتُ النّسا'''}} '''''The Pleasure of Woman''''') is an erotic Indian anecdotehttp://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/07/10/stories/2003071000390100.htm''Lazzat Un Nisa'',translated by Jane Fine, 2002, Classex Books Private Limited, {{ISBN|81-7858-003-9}}, 121 pages.[http://www.hinduonnet.com/thehindu/mp/2003/07/10/stories/2003071000390100.htm The Hindu's article about Lazzat Un Nisa] retrieved Dec 06, 2006''Lazzat un-niso'' Nur publisher, 1991 {{ISBN|5-640-01094-0}} in the [[Persian language]]. It depicts the art of sex through the role of jewellery and perfume in [[lovemaking]], erotic writing as literature, and [[pornography]] as [[aphrodisiac]]. The Book was hand-illustrated and hand-copied in Urdu and Persian in 1850 by writer Mohammed Abdul Latif Muzdar Mehdune. ==History== The original manuscript dates back to the [[Qutb Shahi]] period. In the fifteenth century, the court of [[Bidar]] patronized such erotic works as the [[Bhog bal]], [[Thadkirat al-Shahawat]] (List of aphrodisiacs) and [[Srngaramanjari]] (erotic Bouquets). Lizzat Un Nisa is one of the few surviving erotics works from the period.[https://www.amazon.com/dp/019579334X/ Scent in the Islamic Garden: A Study of Deccani Urdu Literary Sources] {{ISBN|0-19-579334-X}} There is another Kitab ul-Laddhat un-nisa which was written for a certain vizir Kukapondat by the same content and translated from Parsi into Russian. Actually the book itself has no pornographic or explicit sexual bias. It gives instructions how to classify women from their outer aspect starting from their apparel and ending with some parts of their body. In the Middle Ages Central Asia was the most important urbanized complex of cities and the area thrived of scientific research especially in the medical and terapeutic sciences (Avicenna and Rhazes were born there) and therefore it is very interesting to read which, maybe for a man living in these frantic cities, unexpected defaults could show up in the sexual life when making acquaintance with ladies and how he/she could recur to be treated by a doctor and by which special medical recipes. Lately this book became available in Italian with historical comments as per attached bibliography. ==Story== The main subject of the story is a man named Harichand, who under orders of a king, embarks on a journey to collect exotic gifts and beautiful women for the pleasures of the king. The manuscript provides advice on various [[sexual techniques]]. It has a section on how to arouse a woman and observations based on sizes of a woman's vagina and also a brief list of lengths of the phallus. ==References== {{reflist}} 6. Aldo C. Marturano/Haidar Bababekov/Mahmud Hasanov - LE VIRTÙ ATTRATTIVE DELLE DONNE, www.Lulu.com 2016 [[Category:Sex manuals]] [[Category:Indian literature]] [[Category:1850 books]] {{sex-book-stub}} {{manuscript-stub}} {{India-lit-stub}}

A '''sexuality related phobia''' is a fear or dislike of, or a negative attitude towards, a particular type of sexual behavior or people who are identified as or perceived to be members of that group. Sexuality-related phobias refer to reactions ranging from antipathy to contempt, prejudice, aversion, irrational fear, and even hatred.
*[[Biphobia]] – fear/dislike of [[bisexuality]] or bisexuals. *[[Heterophobia]] – fear/dislike of [[heterosexuality]] or heterosexuals. *[[Homophobia]] - fear/dislike of [[homosexuality]] or homosexuals. *[[Lesbophobia]] - fear/dislike of [[lesbians]]. *[[Transphobia]] - fear/dislike of [[transsexuality]] or trans people.

{{More footnotes|date=December 2009}} {{Use American English|date=March 2015}} {{History of war}}
'''Military organization''' or '''military organisation''' is the structuring of the armed forces of a [[State (polity)|state]] so as to offer such [[military capability]] as a [[national defense policy]] may require. In some countries [[paramilitary]] forces are included in a nation's armed forces, though not considered military{{by whom?|date=July 2018}}. Armed forces that are not a part of military or paramilitary organizations, such as [[Insurgency|insurgent]] forces, often [[mimic]] military organizations, or use ''[[ad hoc]]'' structures, while formal military organization tends to use [[hierarchical]] forms.
== History == {{sectstub|date=July 2018}} The use of formalized [[Military rank#Roman ranks|ranks]] in a hierarchical structure came into widespread use with the [[Roman Army]].
In modern times, executive control, management and administration of military organization is typically undertaken by governments through a [[Ministry (government department)|government department]] within the structure of [[public administration]], often known as a [[Ministry of Defense]], [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]], or [[Department of War]]. These in turn manage [[Armed Services]] that themselves command formations and units specialising in combat, [[combat support]] and [[combat service support | combat-service support]].
==Executive control, management and administration== The usually civilian or partly civilian executive control over the national military organization is exercised in [[democracy|democracies]] by an elected political leader as a member of the government's [[Cabinet (government)|Cabinet]], usually known as a Minister of Defense. (In presidential systems, such as the United States, the president is the commander-in-chief, and the cabinet-level defense minister is second in command.) Subordinated to that position are often Secretaries for specific major operational divisions of the armed forces as a whole, such as those that provide general support services to the Armed Services, including their dependants.
Then there are the heads of specific departmental agencies responsible for the provision and management of specific skill- and knowledge-based service such as [[Strategy]] advice, [[Military capability|Capability Development]] assessment, or [[Military science|Defense Science]] provision of research, and design and development of technologies. Within each departmental agency will be found administrative branches responsible for further agency [[business|business specialization]] work.
==Armed services== [[Image:USN-JASDF ship and aircraft formations during ANNUALEX 2008 081119-N-7047S-140.jpg|thumb|A mixed aircraft and ship formation of military vehicles during an exercise with [[United States Navy|USN]] and [[Japan Air Self-Defense Force|JASDF]] vehicles.]] In most countries the ''armed forces'' are divided into three or four [[Armed services]] (also: ''service, military service, or military branch''): [[army]], [[navy]], and [[air force]].
Many countries have a variation on the standard model of three or four basic [[Armed Services]]. Some nations also organize their [[Marines (military)|marines]], [[special forces]] or [[ballistic missile|strategic missile]] forces as independent armed services. A nation's [[coast guard]] may also be an independent [[military branch]] of its military, although in many nations the coast guard is a [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement]] or civil agency. A number of countries have no navy, for geographical reasons. Some other variations include:
* [[Bangladesh]]: [[Bangladesh Army|Army]], [[Bangladesh Navy|Navy]], [[Bangladesh Air Force|Air Force]], [[Border Guards Bangladesh|Border Guards]], [[Bangladesh Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] * [[Brazil]]: [[Brazilian Army|Army]], [[Brazilian Navy|Navy]], [[Brazilian Air Force|Air Force]], [[Military Police (Brazil)|Police]], [[Military Firefighters Corps|Firefighters]] * [[Canada]]: [[Canadian Armed Forces]] * [[Chile]]: [[Chilean Army|Army]], [[Chilean Navy|Navy]], [[Chilean Air Force|Air Force]], [[Carabineros de Chile|National Police]] * [[Croatia]]: [[Croatian Army|Army]], Defense Command|Air Defense]] * [[France]]: [[French Army|Army]], [[French Navy|Navy]], [[French Air Force|Air Force]], [[National Gendarmerie|Gendarmerie]], [[National Guard (France)|National Guard]] Force|Air Force]], [[Vietnam Border Defense Force|Border Guard]], [[Vietnam Marine Police|Coast Guard]]
In larger armed forces the culture between the different [[Armed Services]] of the armed forces can be quite different.
Most smaller countries have a single organization that encompasses all armed forces employed by the country in question. Third-world armies tend to consist primarily of infantry, while first-world armies tend to have larger units manning expensive equipment and only a fraction of personnel in infantry units.
It is worthwhile to make mention of the term ''[[Joint warfare|joint]]''. In western militaries, a [[joint warfare|joint force]] is defined as a unit or formation comprising representation of combat power from two or more branches of the military.
===Internal security forces=== [[Gendarmerie]]s, including equivalents such as [[Internal Troops]], [[Paramilitary|Paramilitary Forces]] and similar, are an internal security service common in most of the world, but uncommon in Anglo-Saxon countries where civil police are employed to enforce the law, and there are tight restrictions on how the armed forces may be used to assist.<ref>In the United States it is a common misunderstanding that their armed forces are totally prohibited from doing so by the [[Posse Comitatus Act]]. This Act, which reserves to Congress the power to employ Federal military force to enforce law and order, refers specifically only to the [[US Army]] and [[US Air Force]]. The [[US Marines]] and [[US Navy|Navy]] are separately regulated, and the [[US Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] has a clear law enforcement role in its peacetime status. The state-controlled [[Army National Guard]] (technically a branch of the US Army) is also excluded from the Posse Comitatus Act. The [[Insurrection Act]] specifically permits the President to use Federal military force to restore public order in extreme emergency situations: this Act was implemented during the [[1992 Los Angeles riots|"Rodney King Riots"]] in Los Angeles.</ref>
{{anchor|Commands.2C_formations.2C_and_units}}
==Commands, formations and units== {{Redirect|Military formation|the arrangement or deployment of moving military forces|Tactical formation}}
It is common, at least in the European and North American militaries, to refer to the building blocks of a military as commands, formations and units.
In a military context, a [[Command (military formation)|command]] is a collection of units and formations under the control of a single officer. Although during the [[Second World War]] a Command was also a name given to a [[Battlegroup (army)|battle group]] in the [[US Army]], in general it is an administrative and executive [[military strategy|strategic]] [[headquarters]] which is responsible to the national government or the national military headquarters. It is not uncommon for a nation's services to each consist of their own command (such as Land Component, Air Component, Naval Component, and Medical Component in the [[Belgian Army]]), but this does not preclude the existence of commands which are not service-based.
{{Anchor|Formation}}A formation is defined by the [[United States Department of Defense|US Department of Defense]] as "two or more aircraft, ships, or units proceeding together under a commander".<ref>[[United States Department of Defense]], [http://www.dtic.mil/doctrine/jel/doddict/data/f/02222.html DOD Dictionary] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223235143/http://www.dtic.mil/doctrine/jel/doddict/data/f/02222.html |date=2008-12-23 }}</ref> Formin in the [[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]] emphasised its combined-arms nature: "Formations are those military organisations which are formed from different speciality Arms and Services troop units to create a balanced, combined combat force. The formations only differ in their ability to achieve different scales of application of force to achieve different strategic, operational and tactical goals and mission objectives."<ref>Fomin, N.N., Great Soviet Encyclopaedia ({{lang-ru|Большая Советская Энциклопедия}}), Moscow, 1978</ref> It is a composite military organization that includes a mixture of integrated and operationally attached sub-units, and is usually combat-capable. Example of formations include: [[Division (military)|division]]s, [[brigade]]s, [[battalion]]s, [[Wing (air force unit)|wings]], etc. Formation may also refer to [[tactical formation]], the physical arrangement or disposition of troops and weapons.<ref>[[Shorter Oxford English Dictionary]]</ref> Examples of formation in such usage include: [[pakfront]], [[panzerkeil]], [[testudo formation]], etc.
A typical unit is a homogeneous military organization (either combat, [[Combat support|combat-support]] or non-combat in capability) that includes service personnel predominantly from a single arm of service, or a branch of service, and its administrative and command functions are self-contained. Any unit subordinate to another unit is considered its sub-unit or minor unit. It is not uncommon for unit and formation to be used synonymously in the United States. In Commonwealth practice, formation is not used for smaller organizations like battalions which are instead called "units", and their constituent [[platoon]]s or [[Company (military unit)|companies]] are referred to as sub-units. In the Commonwealth, formations are [[Division (military)|division]]s, [[brigade]]s, etc.
Different [[armed forces]], and even different branches of service of the armed forces, may use the same name to denote different types of organizations. An example is the "squadron". In most navies a [[Squadron (naval)|squadron]] is a formation of several ships; in most air forces it is a unit; in the U.S. Army it is a battalion-sized [[cavalry]] unit; and in [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] armies a squadron is a company-sized sub-unit.
==Table of organization and equipment== A [[table of organization and equipment]] (TOE or TO&E) is a document published by the U.S. Army Force Management Support Agency that prescribes the organization, manning, and equipage of units from divisional size and down, but also including the headquarters of Corps and Armies.
It also provides information on the mission and capabilities of a unit as well as the unit's current status. A general TOE is applicable to a type of unit (for instance, infantry) rather than a specific unit (the 3rd Infantry Division). In this way, all units of the same branch (such as infantry) follow the same structural guidelines.
==Modern hierarchy== Main article: ''[[Command hierarchy]]'' {{Military units}}
=== Army hierarchy === {{Army units}}
The following table gives an overview of some of the terms used to describe army hierarchy in armed forces across the world. Whilst it is recognized that there are differences between armies of different nations, many are modeled on the [[British Army|British]] or [[United States Armed Forces|American]] models, or both. However, many military units and formations go back in history for a long time, and were devised by various military thinkers throughout European history.
For example, the modern ''Corps'' was first introduced in France about 1805 by Napoleon as a more flexible tactical grouping of two or more divisions during the [[Napoleonic Wars]].
They have become part of the organization of most armies around the world.

Rungs may be skipped in this ladder: for example, typically NATO forces skip from battalion to brigade. Likewise, only large military powers may have organizations at the top levels and different armies and countries may also use traditional names, creating considerable confusion: for example, a British or Canadian armored regiment (battalion) is divided into [[Squadron (army)|squadron]]s (companies) and [[troop]]s (platoons), whereas an American cavalry squadron (battalion) is divided into troops (companies) and platoons.
[[Army]], [[army group]], [[region]], and [[theater (military)|theatre]] are all large formations that vary significantly between armed forces in size and hierarchy position. While [[Division (military)|division]]s were the traditional level at which support elements (field artillery, hospital, logistics and maintenance, etc.) were added to the unit structure, since World War II, many brigades now have such support units, and since the 1980s, regiments also have been receiving support elements. A regiment with such support elements is called a [[regimental combat team]] in US military parlance, or a [[Battlegroup (army)|battle group]] in the UK and other forces.
During [[World War II]] the [[Red Army]] used the same basic organizational structure. However, in the beginning many units were greatly underpowered and their size was actually one level below on the ladder that is usually used elsewhere; for example, a division in the early-WWII Red Army would have been about the size of most nations' regiments or brigades.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://armor.kiev.ua/army/hist/doklad-nko-8-39.shtml |title=Доклад НКО август 1939. doklad-nko-8-39.shtml |publisher=Armor.kiev.ua |date= |accessdate=2013-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://guides.rusarchives.ru/browse/guidebook.html?bid=121&sid=92105 |script-title=ru:Центральный государственный архив Советской армии (с июня 1992 г. Российский государственный военный архив). В двух томах. Том 2. Путеводитель. 1993 |language=ru |publisher=Guides.rusarchives.ru |date= |accessdate=2013-11-20}}</ref> At the top of the ladder, what other nations would call an army group, the Red Army called a [[Front (Soviet Army)|front]]. By contrast, during the same period the German [[Wehrmacht]] Army Groups, particularly on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]], such as [[Army Group Centre]] significantly exceeded the above numbers, and were more cognate with the Soviet [[Strategic Direction]]s.
=== Naval hierarchy === Naval organization at the flotilla level and higher is less commonly abided by, as ships operate in smaller or larger groups in various situations that may change at a moment's notice. However, there is some common terminology used throughout navies to communicate the general concept of how many vessels might be in a unit.
Navies are generally organized into groups for a specific purpose, usually strategic, and these organizational groupings appear and disappear frequently based on the conditions and demands placed upon a navy. This contrasts with army organization where units remain static, with the same men and equipment, over long periods of time.
{| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin:auto; border-collapse:collapse; border:0 none; vertical-align:top;" frame="void" rules="rows" |- style="vertical-align:bottom; border-bottom:3px double #999;" ! align=left | Unit Name ! align=left | Vessel types ! align=left | No. of Vessels ! align=left | Officer in command |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | [[Navy]] or [[Admiralty]] | All vessels in a navy | 2+ Fleets | [[Fleet Admiral]], [[Admiral of the Fleet]], [[Grand Admiral]] or [[Admiral]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | [[Naval fleet|Fleet]] | All vessels in an ocean or general region | 2+ [[Battle Fleet]]s or [[Task Force]]s | [[Admiral]] or [[Vice Admiral]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | [[Battle Fleet]] or [[Task Force]] | A large number of vessels of all types | 2+ [[Task Group]]s | [[Vice Admiral]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | [[Task Group]]<ref>[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/navy/group.htm Group]. GlobalSecurity.org. Retrieved 2009-08-30. </ref> | A collection of complementary vessels | 2+ [[Task Unit]]s or [[Squadron (naval)|Squadron]]s | [[Rear Admiral]] (upper half) or [[Rear Admiral]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | [[Squadron (naval)|Squadron]] or [[Task Unit]] | Usually [[capital ship]]s | A small number of vessels | [[Rear Admiral]] (lower half), [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]], or [[Flotilla Admiral]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | [[Flotilla]] or [[Task Unit]] | Usually not capital ships | A small number of vessels, usually of the same or similar types | [[Rear Admiral]] (lower half), [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]], or [[Flotilla Admiral]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | [[Task force#United States Navy|Task Element]] | A single vessel | One | [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] or [[Commander]] |}
The five-star ranks of Admiral of the Fleet and Fleet Admiral have largely been out of regular use since the 1990s, with the exception of ceremonial or honorary appointments. Currently, all major navies are commanded by an admiral (four-star rank) or vice-admiral (three-star rank) depending on relative size. Smaller naval forces, such as the RNZN, or those navies that are effectively coastguards, are commanded by a rear-admiral (two-star rank), commodore (one-star rank) or even a captain.
Aircraft carriers are typically commanded by a captain. Submarines and destroyers are typically commanded by a captain or commander. Some destroyers, particularly smaller destroyers such as [[frigate]]s (formerly known as [[destroyer escort]]s) are usually commanded by officers with the rank of commander. [[Corvette]]s, the smallest class of warship, are commanded by officers with the rank of commander or lieutenant-commander. Auxiliary ships, including [[gunboat]]s, [[Minesweeper (ship)|minesweepers]], [[patrol boat]]s, military [[riverboat|riverine craft]], [[Ship's tender|tenders]] and [[torpedo boat]]s are usually commanded by lieutenants, sub-lieutenants or warrant officers. Usually, the smaller the vessel, the lower the rank of the ship's commander. For example, patrol boats are often commanded by [[Ensign (rank)|ensign]]s, while frigates are rarely commanded by an officer below the rank of commander.
Historical navies were far more rigid in structure. Ships were collected in divisions, which in turn were collected in numbered squadrons, which comprised a numbered fleet. Permission for a vessel to leave one unit and join another would have to be approved on paper.
The modern U.S. Navy is primarily based on a number of standard groupings of vessels, including the [[carrier strike group]] and the [[Expeditionary Strike Group]].<ref>[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/navy/ US Navy]. GlobalSecurity.org. Retrieved 2009-08-30.</ref>
Additionally, Naval organization continues aboard a single ship. The complement forms three or four departments (such as tactical and engineering), each of which has a number of divisions, followed by work centers.
=== Air Force hierarchy === The organizational structures of air forces vary between nations: some air forces (such as the [[United States Air Force]] and the [[Royal Air Force]]) are divided into commands, groups and squadrons; others (such as the [[Soviet Air Force]]) have an Army-style organizational structure. The modern [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] uses [[Air Division (disambiguation)|Air Division]] as the formation between wings and the entire air command. Like the RAF, Canadian wings consist of squadrons.
{| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin:auto; border-collapse:collapse; border:0 none; vertical-align:top;" frame="void" rules="rows" |- style="vertical-align:bottom; border-bottom:3px double #999;" ! align=left | Symbol (for Army structure comparison) ! align=left | Unit Name ([[United States Air Force|USAF]]/[[Royal Air Force|RAF]]/Other air forces) ! align=left | No. of personnel ! align=left | No. of aircraft ! align=left | No. of subordinate units (USAF/RAF) ! align=left | Officer in command (USAF/RAF) |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | XXXXXX + | [[Air Force]] | Entire air force | Entire air force | All [[USAF#Major Commands|Major Commands]] / [[Command (military formation)|Commands]] | [[General of the Air Force|GAF]] / [[Marshal of the Royal Air Force|MRAF]] or [[Air Chief Marshal|Air Chf Mshl]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | XXXXX | [[USAF#Major Commands|Major Command]]/[[Command (military formation)|Command]] or [[Tactical Air Force]] / Russian [[Air army]]<ref>http://www.airpages.ru/ru/vvs1.shtml Red Army VVS Organisation(rus)</ref> | Varies | Varies | By Region or Duty (subordinate units varies) | [[General|Gen]]/[[Air Chief Marshal|Air Chf Mshl]] or [[Air Marshal|Air Mshl]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | XX | [[Numbered Air Force]]/No RAF equivalent/[[Aviation Division]] /[[Air Division (disambiguation)|Air Division]]/Air Brigade | By Region (subordinate units varies) | Varies | 2+ Wings/Groups | [[Major General|Maj-Gen]] or [[Lieutenant General|Lt-Gen]] / N/A |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | X | [[Wing (air force unit)|Wing]]/[[Group (air force unit)|Group]] (inc. [[No. 83 Expeditionary Air Group (United Kingdom)|EAGs]])/Russian aviation brigade | 1,000–5,000 | 48–100 | 2+ Groups/Wings | [[Brigadier-General|Brig-Gen]]/[[Air Vice-Marshal|AVM]] or [[Air Commodore|Air Cdre]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | III | [[Group (air force unit)|Group]]/[[Wing (air force unit)|Wing]] (inc. [[Expeditionary Air Wing|EAWs]]) or [[RAF station|Station]]/Russian aviation regiment | 300–1,000 | 17–48 | 3–4 [[Squadron (aviation)|Squadron]]s/3–10 [[Flight (military unit)|Flight]]s | [[Colonel|Col]]/[[Group Captain|Gp Capt]] or [[Wing Commander (rank)|Wg Cdr]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | II | [[Squadron (aviation)|Squadron]] | 100–300 | 7–16 | 3–4 [[Flight (military unit)|Flight]]s | [[Lieutenant Colonel|Lt Col]] or [[Major|Maj]]/[[Wing Commander (rank)|Wg Cdr]] or [[Squadron Leader|Sqn Ldr]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | ••• | [[Flight (military unit)|Flight]] | 20–100 | 4–6 | 2 [[Section (military unit)|Section]]s plus maintenance and support crew | [[Captain (land and air)|Capt]]/[[Squadron Leader|Sqn Ldr]] or [[Flight Lieutenant|Flt Lt]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | •• | [[Section (military unit)|Element or Section]] | 5–20 | n/a–2 | n/a | [[Junior Officer]] or [[Senior NCO]] |- style="vertical-align:top; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" | • | [[Section (military unit)|Detail]] | 2–4 | n/a | n/a | [[Junior NCO]] |}
==Task force== A [[task force]] is a unit or formation created as a temporary grouping for a specific operational purpose. Aside from administrative hierarchical forms of organization that have evolved since the early 17th century in Europe, fighting forces have been grouped for specific operational purposes into mission-related organizations such as the German [[Kampfgruppe]] or the U.S. Combat Team (Army) and Task Force (Navy) during the Second World War, or the Soviet [[Operational manoeuvre group]] during the Cold War. In the British and Commonwealth armies the [[Battlegroup (army)|battlegroup]] became the usual grouping of companies during the [[Second World War]] and the Cold War.
Within NATO, a [[Joint Task Force]] (JTF) would be such a temporary grouping that includes elements from more than one armed service, a Combined Task Force (CTF) would be such a temporary grouping that includes elements from more than one nation, and a Combined Joint Task Force (CJTF) would be such a temporary grouping that includes elements of more than one armed service and more than one nation.

The '''National Atmospheric Release Advisory Center''' (NARAC) is located at the University of California's [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]]. It is a national support and resource center for planning, real-time assessment, emergency response, and detailed studies of incidents involving a wide variety of hazards, including nuclear, radiological, chemical, biological, and natural emissions.
NARAC provides tools and services to federal, state and local governments, that map the probable spread of hazardous material accidentally or intentionally released into the atmosphere.
NARAC provides [[atmospheric dispersion modeling|atmospheric plume predictions]] in time for an emergency manager to decide if protective action is necessary to protect the health and safety of people in affected areas.
== The NARAC facility includes ==
* Scientific and technical staff who provide support and training for NARAC tools, as well as quality assurance and detailed analysis of atmospheric releases. * 24 hour x 7 day on-duty or on-call staff. * Training facility. * An Operations Center with uninterruptible power, backup power generators, and robust computer systems. * Links to over 100 emergency operations centers on the U.S. * A team of research and operational staff with expertise in atmospheric research, operational meteorology, numerical modeling, computer science, software engineering, geographical information systems, computer graphics, hazardous material (radiological, chemical, biological) properties and effects.
==The Emergency Response System: Real time dispersion modeling==
The NARAC emergency response central modeling system consists of an integrated suite of [[meteorology|meteorological]] and [[atmospheric dispersion modeling|atmospheric dispersion models]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Turner, D.B.|title=Workbook of atmospheric dispersion estimates: an introduction to dispersion modeling|edition=2nd|publisher=CRC Press|year=1994|isbn=1-56670-023-X}} [http://www.crcpress.com/shopping_cart/products/product_detail.asp?sku=L1023&parent_id=&pc= www.crcpress.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071105075907/http://www.crcpress.com/shopping_cart/products/product_detail.asp?sku=L1023&parent_id=&pc= |date=2007-11-05 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Beychok, M.R.|title=[[Fundamentals Of Stack Gas Dispersion]]|edition=4th|publisher=author-published|year=2005|isbn=0-9644588-0-2}} [http://www.air-dispersion.com www.air-dispersion.com]</ref> The meteorological [[data assimilation]] model, ADAPT, constructs fields of such variables as the mean [[wind]]s, [[pressure]], [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]], [[temperature]], and [[turbulence]].<ref>Sugiyama, G., and S. T. Chan (1998), ''A New Meteorological Data Assimilation Model for Real-Time Emergency Response'', 10th Joint Conference on the Applications of Air Pollution Meteorology, Phoenix, Arizona, January, 1998.</ref> Non-divergent wind fields are produced by a procedure based on the variational principle and a [[finite element method|finite-element discretization]]. The dispersion model, LODI, solves the 3-D advection-diffusion equation using a [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|Lagrangian]] [[stochastic]], [[Monte Carlo method]].<ref>Ermak, D.L., and J.S. Nasstrom (2000), ''A Lagrangian Stochastic Diffusion Method for Inhomogeneous Turbulence'', Atmospheric Environment, 34, 7, 1059-1068.</ref> LODI includes methods for simulating the processes of mean wind advection, turbulent diffusion, radioactive decay and production, bio-agent degradation, first-order chemical reactions, [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|wet deposition]], gravitational settling, [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|dry deposition]], and [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|buoyant]]/momentum plume rise.
The models are coupled to NARAC databases providing topography, geographical data, chemical-biological-nuclear agent properties and health risk levels, real-time meteorological observational data, and global and mesoscale forecast model predictions. The NARAC modeling system also includes an in-house version of the Naval Research Laboratory's mesoscale weather forecast model COAMPS.<ref>Hodur, R. M. (1997), ''The Navel Research Laboratory's Coupled Ocean/Atmosphere Mesoscale Prediction System (COAMPS)'', Mon. Wea. Rev., 125, 1414-1430.</ref>
== See also== * [[Materials MASINT]] * [[Accidental release source terms]] * [[Air Resources Laboratory]] * [[Air Quality Modeling Group]] * [[Atmospheric dispersion modeling]] * [[Department of Public Safety]] * [[National Center for Atmospheric Research]] * [[University Corporation for Atmospheric Research]]

The '''Norwegian Institute for Urban and Regional Research''' ({{lang-no|Norsk institutt for by- og regionforskning}}, NIBR) is a [[social science]] [[research institute]] based in [[Oslo]], [[Norway]]. It is a part of the [[CIENS|Oslo Centre for Interdisciplinary Environmental and Social Research]] cooperative umbrella organization. Its purpose is to conduct "studies which promote society's ability to tackle environmental and social development challenges". The current director general of NIBR is dr. polit Hilde Lorentzen. '''Departments'''
NIBR has four departments: - Dept. for Housing and Environmental Planning Research - Dept. for International Studies in Development, Transition and Migration - Dept. for Socioeconomic and Territorial Studies - Dept. for Welfare, Democracy and Governance Research ==External links== * [http://en.nibr.no/ Official website] [[Category:Research institutes in Norway]] [[Category:Education in Oslo]] [[Category:Independent research institutes]] [[Category:Social science institutes]] [[Category:Urban studies and planning schools]] {{Norway-org-stub}}

'''Novim''' is a non-profit group at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] that organizes teams for objective scientific study of global issues and identification options for addressing the concerns, based upon an collaborative problem-solving approach used in the field of physics.
== Overview == The group was formed at the University of California campus in Santa Barbara to create a collaborative problem-solving approach to address widespread and complicated problems, modeled after approaches at the [[Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics]] (KITP). Novim organizes study teams of scientists, researchers, and area experts to evaluate issues like [[climate engineering]], [[global surface temperature]]s, and [[Environmental impact of hydraulic fracturing in the United States|methane leakage]]s in [[natural gas]] production. Their criteria for issue selection is that it must be "highly complex, controversial and global." They partner with governmental organizations, like the [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]] and [[Office of Science]], to engage them in the process, share findings and discuss potential actions.<ref name=Cooper>{{Cite news|url=http://www.noozhawk.com/article/011410_undersecretary_of_science_talks_sustainability_at_ucsb/|title= Undersecretary for Science Talks Sustainability at UCSB|date=2010-01-14|accessdate=2010-01-14}}</ref><ref name=Fernandez>{{Cite news|url=http://www.noozhawk.com/article/090609_novim_global_issues/|title= Novim Aims to Close Information Gap on Pressing Global Issues|date=2009-09-06|accessdate=2009-09-06}}</ref>
Jim Knight is Novim's executive vice president and Michael Ditmore is its executive director, both of whom are Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics (KITP) Director’s Council members.<ref name=Fernandez />
== Advisory board == *[[David Auston]], Executive Director of the Center for Energy Efficient Materials at [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] *Tom Everhart, President Emeritus, [[Caltech]] *[[David Gross]], Nobel Laureate. Director, UCSB Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics *[[Steven Koonin]], Founding Director of the NYU Center for Urban Science and Progress, Brooklyn, NY *[[James S. Langer]], Past President, [[American Physical Society]] *Aristides Patrinos, Senior VP Corporate Affairs, Synthetic Genomics *Venkatesh Narayanamurti, Former Dean, Harvard School of Engineering & Applied Science
== Projects ==
===Geoengineering Study=== They first studied the changes in the Earth's average surface temperature and published their findings in 2009 in the ''Climate Engineering Study Group'' report.{{#tag:ref|The [[International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis| International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)]] announced Novim's first report in August 2009.<ref name="IIASA" />|group="nb"}} They found that there was a need to use [[climate engineering|geoengineering]] to lower the Earth's average temperature and suggested adopting the principles of short wave climate engineering (SWCE) to introduce aerosols into the stratosphere. Much like the sulfur particles released by large volcanic eruptions, the aerosols would reflect shortwave solar radiation back into space to cool the air and land below.<ref name="IIASA">[http://www.iiasa.ac.at/Admin/INF/PR/2009/2009-08-03.html Climate intervention: what we need to know to respond to a climate emergency]</ref> Although SWCE may help reverse global warming, the technique remains untested and potential adverse effects are unknown, and therefore could not be mitigated.<ref>Jonathan Tirone, [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ah33HPW4.Jr8 "Geo-Engineering Risks Weigh on Hopes to Reverse Global Warming"], [https://www.bloomberg.com/ ''Bloomberg''], Published 3 August 2009, Retrieved 14 October 2012.</ref> Opponents have stated that the core causes are not addressed, only the symptoms, and that SWCE would damage the ozone.<ref>Hands Off Mother Earth, [http://www.handsoffmotherearth.org/learn-more/what-is-geoengineering/sulphate-aerosols-artificial-volcanoes/ "Sulphate Aerosols & Artificial volcanoes"]</ref>
Novim collected an international team of scientists to work together on the study,<ref>CIGI Online, [http://www.cigionline.org/articles/2009/08/cigi-fellow-studies-geoengineering "CIGI Fellow Studies Geoengineering"], [http://www.cigionline.org/ ''Centre for International Governance Innovation (CIGI)''], Published 5 August 2009, Retrieved 14 October 2012.</ref> which was performed on a small scale to make options available as soon as reasonably possible.<ref name="Tierney" />{{#tag:ref|Dr. Ken Caldeira advocates for small scale testing to be performed soon so that a working system could, at the very least, be designed and ready in event of a large-scale climate crisis<ref name="Tierney">John Tierney, [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/11/science/11tier.html "Is the Earth Warming? Adjust the Thermostat"], The New York Times: 10 August 2009.</ref> which requires rapid global action.<ref>Joe Romm, [http://thinkprogress.org/romm/2009/08/29/204567/science-risks-of-climate-geo-engineering-hegerl-susan-solomon/ "Science on the Risks of Climate Engineering: 'Optimism about a geoengineered ‘easy way out’ should be tempered by examination of currently observed climate changes'"], ThinkProgress, published 29 August 2009</ref>|group="nb"}} They determined that the cost to deploying the methods described in the study would be about $8 billion USD per year if delivered by aircraft.<ref>Tom McNichol, [http://www.good.is/post/engineering-a-better-climate/ "Engineering a Better Climate"], GOOD, published 11 January 2010</ref> {{#tag:ref| The paper was submitted to peer review in 2009 at the IOP Conference Series<ref>[http://iopscience.iop.org/1755-1315/6/45/452015 D Battisti et al], 2009 IOP Conf. Ser.: Earth Environ. Sci. 6 452015 doi:10.1088/1755-1307/6/45/452015</ref> and the IIASA GGI Seminar.<ref>Jason Blackstock, [http://www.iiasa.ac.at/Research/GGI/ "Developing Climate Engineering Responses to Climate Emergencies: Scientific Assessments and Policy Implications of Geoengineering Research"], International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA) Greenhouse Gas Initiative Seminar: July 2009.</ref> Novim has also made the paper available for free online at [[Arxiv.org]].<ref>[https://arxiv.org/pdf/0907.5140 Climate Engineering Responses to Climate Emergencies] .</ref> Since its release, Novim's Geoengineering Study has become a common reference in peer academic studies on the subject, including a [[United States House of Representatives]] Report,<ref>Chairman Bart Gordon, Committee on Science and Technology, U.S. House of Representatives, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/nation/pdfs/Geongineeringreport.pdf "Engineering the Climate: Research Needs and Strategies for International Coordination Report"], 111th Congress 2nd Session: October 2010.</ref> an article in [[Science (journal)|Science]],<ref>Gabriele C. Heger and Susan Solomon, [http://www.sciencemag.org/content/325/5943/955.summary "Climate Change: Risks of Climate Engineering"], Science Magazine, Issue 21, August 2009: Vol. 325 no. 5493 pp. 955-956, DOI: 10.1126/science.1178530</ref> the Journal of Geophysical Research,<ref>Caspar M. Ammann, et. al, [http://nldr.library.ucar.edu/repository/assets/osgc/OSGC-000-000-000-884.pdf "Climate Engineering through artificial enhancement of natural forcings: Magnitudes and implied consequences"], Journal of Geophysical Research, Vol. 115, D22109, 2010.</ref> and the International Seminar on Nuclear War and Planetary Emergencies.<ref>A. Zichichi (Series Editor and Chairman), [https://books.google.com/books?id=E3PfuJmNuOcC International Seminar on Nuclear War and Planetary Emergencies 42nd Session], "E. Majorana" Centre for Scientific Culter, Erice, Italy: 19–24 August 2009.</ref> The study has also appeared on the suggested reading lists at the Trottier Symposium,<ref>Suggested Reading List, [https://www.mcgill.ca/science/events/trottier-symposium/2009/readings Trottier Symposium], McGill University, Montreal, Canada: 2009.</ref> the Denver Climate Study Group,<ref>Associated background, Denver Climate Study Group: [http://www.denverclimatestudygroup.com/20-19TH_Meeting20091110_GEOENGINEERING_SOL-SHAPIRO/index.htm "Geoengineering - Why? and the next steps"], Denver, CO: 10 November 2009</ref> and the International Risk Governance Council meeting on geoengineering.<ref>[http://people.ucalgary.ca/~keith/Bibliography2.html Annotated Bibliography on Climate Engineering], International Risk Governance Council meeting on geoengineering, Lisbon: April 2009.</ref>|group="nb"|name=""}}
===Berkeley Earth Surface Temperature (BEST) Study===
Novim's second study was the [[Berkeley Earth Surface Temperature]] Study (BEST), released 29 July 2012.<ref>Lauren Morello, [https://www.nytimes.com/cwire/2011/04/01/01climatewire-experts-heat-up-over-berkeley-lab-scientists-q-490.html "Experts Heat Up Over Berkeley Lab Scientist's Quest to 'Calm' Climate Change Debate"], ''The New York Times'', Published 1 April 2011, Retrieved 14 October 20121.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Muller|first=Elizabeth|title=250 Years of Global Warming|url=http://berkeleyearth.org/pdf/berkeley-earth-press-release-july-29.pdf|publisher=Berkeley Earth|accessdate=25 December 2012|date=29 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021061031/http://berkeleyearth.org/pdf/berkeley-earth-press-release-july-29.pdf|archivedate=21 October 2012|df=}}</ref> The study reanalyzes the world's land temperature data following the [[Climatic Research Unit email controversy]].<ref>Ian Sample, [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/oct/20/global-warming-study-climate-sceptics "Global warming study finds no grounds for climate sceptics' concerns"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', Published 20 October 2011, Retrieved 14 October 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Summary of Results|url=http://berkeleyearth.org/results-summary/|publisher=Berkeley Earth|accessdate=25 December 2012}}</ref> Professor [[Richard A. Muller]] led the study team that included 2011 [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] winner [[Saul Perlmutter]].<ref>[http://www.economist.com/node/21533360?fsrc=rss%7Csct "The heat is on"], ''The Economist'', From the print edition 22 October 2011, Retrieved 14 October 2012.</ref><ref>Richard A. Muller, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204422404576594872796327348 "The Case Against Global-Warming Skepticism"], ''The Wall Street Journal'', 21 October 2011.</ref>{{#tag:ref|Results are available via the BEST website,<ref>{{cite web|title=Dataset Summary|url=http://berkeleyearth.org/dataset/|publisher=Berkeley Earth|accessdate=25 December 2012}}</ref> as well as through the [https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/just-science/id480905653?mt=8 "Just Science" iOS app].|group="nb"}}
=== Methane Leakage === Methane Leakage - Novim has assembled a team of scientific and technical experts to analyze existing studies of the emissions profile of natural gas during the production and distribution phases, with a focus on determining a range of actual methane leakage rates. Probable causes for the leakage will be included, and proposed solutions will be examined, along with associated costs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phase I Meta Study of Methane Leakage|url=http://www.novim.org/projects/natural-gas|publisher=Novim|accessdate=25 December 2012}}</ref>

'''Pathosformel''' or "pathos formula" (German plural: ''pathosformeln'') is a term coined by the German art historian and cultural theorist [[Aby Warburg]] (1866–1929) in his research on the afterlife of antiquity (''das Nachleben der Antike''). It is described as "the primitive words of passionate gesture language"<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Sliwinski |first1=Sharon |title=New York Transfixed |journal=Review of Education, Pedagogy, and Cultural Studies |date=14 June 2008 |volume=30 |pages=246–247 |url=http://www.torontophotographyseminar.org/sites/default/files/uploads/Sliwinski_New_York_Transfixed.pdf}}</ref> and the "emotionally charged visual trope[s]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Becker|first1=Colleen|title=Aby Warburg's Pathosformel as methodological paradigm|journal=Journal of Art Historiography|date=2013|issue=9}}</ref> that recur throughout images in Western Europe. While the term is associated with [[Formalism (art)|formalism]], Warburg restricts the concept to cultural-psychological themes, as he held "an honest disgust of aestheticizing art history".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forster|first1=Kurt|last2=Britt|first2=David|title=Aby Warbug: His Study of Ritual and Art on Two Continents|journal=The MIT Press|date=1996|volume=77|pages=6}}</ref> Despite its name, pathosformel does not provide a calculable formula to identify visual links among images. Instead, it calls on collective and individual imagination to find such links apart from those based on age, type, size, or origin. In historian Kurt Forster's words, "it exerts its control over existing figurations in a way that endows them with new, 'sign-giving' qualities."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forster|first1=Kurt|last2=Britt|first2=David|title=Aby Warbug: His Study of Ritual and Art on Two Continents|journal=The MIT Press|date=1996|volume=77|pages=21–22}}</ref> The art historian [[Ernst Gombrich]], described pathosformel as "the primeval reaction of man to the universal hardships of his existence [that] underlies all his attempts at mental orientation".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gombrich|first1=Ernst Hans|title=Aby Warburg: An Intellectual Biography|date=1986|publisher=Phaidon|isbn=0714824275|page=223|url=https://books.google.fr/books/about/Aby_Warburg.html?id=agfqAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y}}</ref>
[[File:Sandro_Botticelli_-_La_nascita_di_Venere_-_Google_Art_Project_-_edited.jpg|thumb|Botticelli's ''The Birth of Venus'' c. 1486.]] Warburg's early work on paintings by [[Sandro Botticelli|Botticelli]] and [[Domenico Ghirlandaio|Ghirlandaio]] as well as his later work on the reappearance of astrological symbols in artwork and popular ephemera employ the concept of pathosformel.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forster|first1=Kurt|last2=Britt|first2=David|title=Aby Warbug: His Study of Ritual and Art on Two Continents|journal=The MIT Press|date=1996|volume=77|pages=5}}</ref> His dissertation, completed in 1893 presents an early formulation of the concept in comparing Botticelli's [[The Birth of Venus|Birth of Venus]] with [[Primavera (painting)|Primavera]] by looking at the ''bewegtes Beiwerk'' or "animated incident" that appears among them. To Warburg, this incident is the depiction of wind that animates the paintings. In the former, it is seen in Venus's flowing hair, while in the latter, it is seen in the flowing dress of the nymph Flora on the far right.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rampley|first1=Mathew|title=From Symbol to Allegory: Aby Warburg's Theory of Art|journal=The Art Bulletin|date=1997|volume=79|issue=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forster|first1=Kurt|last2=Britt|first2=David|title=Aby Warbug: His Study of Ritual and Art on Two Continents|journal=The MIT Press|date=1996|volume=77|pages=19}}</ref>[[File:Botticelli-primavera.jpg|thumb|left|Botticelli's ''Primavera'' c. 1482.]]
In 1905, Warburg presented a lecture on Dürer and Italian Antiquity, in which he used pathosformel to approach images by [[Dürer]], [[Andrea Mantegna]], Antonio Pollaiuolo and others from the point of view of a historical psychology of human expression.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Forster|first1=Kurt|last2=Britt|first2=David|last3=Warburg|first3=Aby|title=The Renewal of Pagan Antiquity: Contributions to the Cultural History of the European Renaissance|date=1999|publisher=Getty Research Institute for the History of Art and the Humanities|isbn=978-0892365371}}</ref>
Warburg's unfinished montage, the Mnemosyne Atlas provides another example of the pathosformel.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rampley|first1=Mathew|title=From Symbol to Allegory: Aby Warburg's Theory of Art|journal=The Art Bulletin|date=1997|volume=79|issue=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forster|first1=Kurt|last2=Britt|first2=David|title=Aby Warbug: His Study of Ritual and Art on Two Continents|journal=The MIT Press|date=1996|volume=77|pages=19}}</ref> There, Warburg pairs a [[Dürer]] engraving from [[Apocalypse (Dürer)|Apocalypse with Pictures]] (1498) with an image featured in a popular tarot illustrated by the same artist (1494/5). While the image of the chariot links these works compositionally, the chariot itself signifies for Warburg the need to control a potentially disastrous conflict, thus linking similar psychological dynamics in different works regardless of their high or low cultural origins.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Becker|first1=Colleen|title=Aby Warburg's Pathosformel as methodological paradigm|journal=Journal of Art Historiography|date=2013|page=11|issue=9}}</ref> Warburg acknowledged, however, that the persistence of a motif does not necessarily carry with it the same meaning.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Posècq|first1=Avigdor|title=Left and Right Orientation of a Pathosformel in Dürer|journal=Notes in the History of Art|date=1996|volume=16|issue=1|pages=7–17}}</ref>
Pathosformel is closely related to, albeit distinct from [[Robert Vischer]]'s notion of [[empathy]] (Einfühlung), which Warburg refers to as the "force active in the generation of style".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rampley|first1=Mathew|title=From Symbol to Allegory: Aby Warburg's Theory of Art|journal=The Art Bulletin|date=1997|volume=79|issue=1|page=44}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Aby Warburg]] * [[Jungian archetypes]] * [[Einfühlung]] * [[Affect theory]]
